title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the US will be reported for the week ending 1 May 2021?
preds: This may feel easy, but it isn't. 5 days ~ 3200, 2 more days to go!  1300 deaths in 2 days still seems more likely than not.  I took a look at Covid ICU occupation (clearly I should have done this earlier!) and it seemed to me that deaths, very roughly ~ 10% of Covid ICU (in a given week). Note, I hadn't done a regression. Now for the last couple of weeks, Covid ICU occupation went up from ~9k to 10k. I don't know if it means anything, it's quite possible that (since there is enough capacity) that lower risk patients are admitted to ICU just to be safe.  Anyway, all this to say, I am still going to err on the conservative (higher side).  Seems like 30-70 to me.

Will there be another 1,220 deaths today and tomorrow in the U.S. from COVID?  It is going to be close.  Based on the numbers from the past two days, I think that it is highly likely that the number will be over 4,500, thus flipping my forecast to favor "4,500 to 6,000."  Hopefully, we can get today's numbers before the question closes tonight.
If the trends of this week (numbers are 94% of last week) continue, the number is going to be 4604.

As of April 28th, there have been around 2,200 deaths this week. With three days left and a daily death count ranging from 300 to 900 (mainly around 500), the death count of the week will probably fall either a little less than 4,500 or a little more, making the prediction tricky.
Changing forecast to reflect current information
It is going to be close, but considering that hospitalizations are declining is week as well, I am increasing my forecast on "3,000 to 4,500".

Wednesday didn’t fit the trend, +12% compared to Wednesday last week. Sunday to Wednesday in sum 95% of last week. 
95% of 4901	(sum last week) = 4643, therefore going back to 80% for 4500-6000.
Day	   /    Last week /	This week /	% of last week
Sun	        318	        	  279	  	          88%
Mon	482		          474	        	  98%
Tue	        825		          641	        	  78%
Wed	844	        	  945	        	112%
Su-We  2469	        	2339	        	  95%
Update 4/28: 1525 deaths April 25-27. 1675 deaths April 18-20. 9.0% fewer so far this week. On April 24, 7-day average was 718/day. 0.91 * 718/day = 653.4/day. 653.4 * 7 = 4574. Very close forecast.

It is going to be close around 4,500 deaths for the week going plus or minus either way.  We are going to be completely in the dark on which way the question will go when forecasting closes.  Making a very minor forecast adjustment to account for how close this is going to be.

This is suddenly getting very interesting:
1457 deaths until yesterday (3 days April 25-27), 
4 days left (April 28 - May 1).
4500-1457 = 3043 deaths to reach 4500.
A week ago (April 21-April 24), there were 3272 deaths in the last four days of the week.
3043 (to reach 4500 this week) would be 93% of 3272.
So far, in this week (April 25-27) there were 90% of the deaths of a week earlier (April 18-20).
If for rest of the week it will also be 90% of the previous week, it is going to be 4396, in the end. So I am changing the forecast substantially:
4500-6000: 90% > 50%
3000-4500: 10% > 50%

Fitting a curve to the deaths in recent weeks gives an estimated 4.8k, hence almost all weight to 4.5k-6k - 97%
Small chance number will be much higher or lower due to reporting/data issues - 1% and 2% respectively

Going up a bit to 90% for 4500+
April 25 + 26: 745 deaths = 93% of April 18 + 19.
If the entire week is 93% of week earlier: 4569 deaths.
Will be a close call.
Changing forecast based on updated information estimate.

I agree with CJH's analysis.  It appears that the number is going to be right round 4,500, give or take over/under.  For now, I am keeping my forecast as is and believe that deaths will continue to decline throughout the week.  Will make adjustments based on data throughout the week accordingly.

Sunday numbers (April 25, not final) -11%, compared to Sunday April 18th.
If for every weekday from now on shows 11% less than a week earlier, it will be 4435 for the entire week.
rolling weekly numbers hovering around 4900, so 6000 + rather unlikely

Using a curve fitting approach to deaths - new central estimate = approx. 4.7k - 75% weight
Based on curve fitting, still a chance deaths will come under 4.5k, particularly if reporting patterns are delayed somewhat - 23% weight
Also included 2% chance of >6k. We've previously had backlogs of deaths which have been reported late all at once. Would give potential for much higher number that week. - 2% weight
Death count drop was slower than expected.

Based on data believe that the number is going to be right around 5,000 deaths with a range of 4,000 to 5,500 deaths.  There are conflicting factors, some areas of the United States are surging while other are on the decline.  However, overall weekly deaths are declining.  I believe it will be close between "3,000 to 4,500" and "4,500 to 6,000."  Made adjustments accordingly.
Adjusting forecast due to passage of time and progress.

Deaths from COVID appears to be on a rapid decline.  The small spike of a couple of weeks ago appears to have not been as bad as initially projected as vaccination rates continue to increase.  The pleasant weather of the past couple of weeks for most of the county probably contributed to the decline as well.  As a lagging indicator, probably see a low death count from COVID next week.
I seem to have fat fingered the prev forecast.
Deaths have been on a downward trend and they went below 5K for the week ending Apr 17. However deaths don't reduce as dramatically as cases can.
Rate fairly steady about 720 ish per day.

I fit a couple of curves to the weekly deaths, projecting this trend suggested approx. 3.8k as central pick. - 65% weight - 3k-4.5k
There is a chance decay will slow down (possibly due to new variants) - 30% weight - 4.5k - 6k
Chance deaths drop significantly more than expected as a result of vaccines - 5% weight - 1.5k-3k

Update. Cases are declining because of vaccinations much faster than I thought they would. It appears that some backlogs were recently reported and that those are superimposed on a secular trend that is downward, in spite of a generally slightly upward trend in cases 3 weeks ago. But, the cases/day 3 weeks before the end of the month (relevant as deaths lag cases by 3 weeks) are only very slightly higher than now, so the numbers of deaths we see for the last week of the month should be at most very slightly higher than now, or more realistically, a bit lower due to increasing vaccination rates. So if deaths are trending at ~720/day now, that's 5040 for a week. <4500 => <643 cases/day; I don't think that's likely within the next couple weeks. I think death rates/day for the forecast period will likely average between ~670/day and ~720/day, based on recent declines.
@Raven Pandemic fatigue.  Lack of coherent plans.  Lack of coordination.  Lack of cooperation!

Si bien durante su winter break alcanzaron a tener cerca de 4000 muertes diarias, ya finalizadas las vacaciones volvieron a estabilizarse con cerca de 1000 muertes diarias. El proceso de vacunación esta siendo exitoso por lo que no debiese haber otro outbreak de muertes tan grande como el de diciembre y enero, es por esto que la mayor probabilidad de 50% es que hayan al rededor de  1000 casos diarios durante la ultima semana de abril, que la sigue un pronostico agradable con el 30% de que este haciendo efecto la vacuna, y reduzcan sus muertes. Las dos colas del forecast tienen un 10% cada una por si se afecta la proyección real con comportamientos inusuales de los estadounidenses, ya sea empezar a cuidarse mas o todo lo contrario.

The daily rates since the Easter peak are in line with pre Easter suggesting that tomorrow, when the peak drops out of the 7 day rolling average it will drop back to 750 per day.  Revising forecast back to that range.

At the moment the us is by 5300 deaths per week. I think it´s falling in the next weeks because of many people would be vaccinated the 1st and 2nd time, which means less covid-19 cases and less deaths. 
Also the numbers going down past weeks and there is no reason why it schouldn´t be diffrent in the next weeks.
Most predictions seem between 5,000 and 5,600, deaths on downward trend.

We're at about 5300 deaths per week right now, but the rate is falling.  Things are opening up and there are new, more contagious variants.  Case rates are rising relative to the drop in the late winter. However, the number of persons vaccinated is rising rapidly, and a large number of vulnerable Americans are either fully vaccinated or will be shortly (they have already had two doses, or have a 2nd dose scheduled). The death rate fell more slowly that I expected, in part due, I think to a tendency for the vulnerable to be careful.  So we vaccinated a lot of people who weren't likely to die because they were taking other precautions.  Those people can now participate more broadly while remaining safe, but that didn't show up in the death rate.  Now, however, the vaccine is much more broadly deployed, so I expect the downward trend to continue. But it's hard to tell how far. And the variants could ease cause it to rise again.
Adjusting previous forecast because the high one day was catch up for Easter I think, which I totally forgot about. Range likely to be in 750 to 1.1k per day range.
Although cases are surging, the number of deaths continues to decline as hospital treatments gain efficacy and doctors gain experience.
Update to reflect effects of vaccinations. New forecast for ~6.9k deaths in the forecast period, possibly a bit less.

Current rate just shy of 1k per day which is 7k for the week.  
Jump causes by one day peak likely due to back reporting.  Average prior to this was 750 per day = 5.2k.  Average likely to drop back closer to this when the peak day is more than 7 days ago.
Threshold of 4.5k = 642 per day
Threshold for 6k = 850 per day
Threshold for 7.5k = 1.05k per day Vaccines should limit numbers of deaths now even if cases rise.  Cases have crept up too in the past 3 weeks and so this will cause a slight increase to deaths in the next 3 weeks. If it drops back to the

Sadly, the number of deaths is largely foretold now in the number of cases. Deaths lag cases by about 3 weeks. Currently just under 1.0k deaths/day 7 day moving average right now, resulting from when there were ~54k cases/day 3 weeks ago. Cases now will result in deaths in the forecast period. Cases now are in the ballpark of 65k/day = 1.2 * 54k. If one assumes the ratio of deaths to cases stays relatively constant over a 3 week period, then the deaths in 3 weeks should be ~ 1.2 * 1.0k/day * 7 days = 8.4k. This might be a slight overestimate, but probably not by much.

Current numbers will probably rise in next few days, then decline. At least that's how I see it, considering increasing numbers of vaccination in the ones most likely to die. The current increase in numbers is going to stabilize and then decline... that said only 30 days for all these changes.

According to the CDC, the current weekly death toll is 1,610. However, also according to the CDC, the death rate is declining with the 7-day average of daily deaths declining compared to the prior weekly average. That said, cases are up in five states across the country according to NPR, which means we'll most likely see a spike in cases, which could throw deaths up a bit. But I'm betting they'll stay largely the same.

Expecting rate to continue to decline, albeit at a slower rate, through mitigating factors such as first dose vaccine rollout, less pressure on heath system, greater protection of elderly. After comparing with other countries experiencing increasing transmission rates, I don't see this halting the downward trend of deaths for the next few weeks, an should slow the decline only marginally.
Forecast 3,700-4,900

Current rate = 775/day (rolling average) = 5,425/week. Declining trend. https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/ Vaccination rate = 34%. Vaccine projection for 1 May is ~ 50%. This will support on-going death rate reduction. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/covid-19-vaccine-doses.html#projection Estimate reduction of 20% = 620/day = 4,300/week

Brief summary of info I'm using to make the prediction: -The COVID19 forecast hub ensemble model projects around 5,400 that week, with a 95% confidence interval of 2,300 to 10,000. https://viz.covid19forecasthub.org/ -Over 70% of people over 65 have gotten one dose of the vaccine, and the vaccines have a nearly 100% effectiveness against severe illness and death. Although not fully vaccinated, I've seen reason to believe that one dose offers most of that protection as well: https://www.nbc12.com/2021/03/24/cdc-people-over-got-dose-vaccine/ -Cases lag deaths by roughly 3 weeks, and the US deaths have now caught up with the drop in cases, so the steep drop in cases should all be accounted for by now, change in deaths going forward is going to be due to vaccine protection and any future change in cases lagged by ~3 weeks. The 3 week lag and short time frame on this question leads me to believe cases throughout the month won't have a big impact on this due to lag time. https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1tY8FgmbrvY6a0JI7Fm0QiabMhUpia6eRIC3ve1Oy-wY/edit?usp=sharing -75% of deaths are in age 65 and over. (Note the source for the charts and data I used is CDC data which has up to an 8 week lag, data more recent than 8 weeks old shouldn't be relied on). https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/10dmp4q82-cZhCkxcDPcimo0poNBnISbsn_kEbiIQ2dY/edit?usp=sharing Putting that all together I think deaths are more likely to slowly drop going forward and I think deaths will be decoupled from cases to an extent due to protection among the elderly. So I'm putting most weight in 4,500 to 6,000 and I think the trajectory the ensemble model projects is most likely and supported by the other factors I mentioned. I also put a little more weight on buckets lower than 4,500 than higher than 6,000 due to vaccinations in the elderly, but am still leaving room for the possibility that I'm wrong and that cases and deaths increase this month. Data from Our World in Data uses the same source data so linking for reference: https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+deaths&Interval=Weekly&Relative+to+Population=false&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA
The trend is effected by Spring break.

Please note my comments on other questions but it's well known, isn't it, that data is inconsistenly gathered, defined and delivered, but as a first approax I think we must ignore those factors -- for the moment  Therefore, for the moment, I want to call these pristine  Covid phenomena and events.

Vaccines should be establishing foot hold by May 1.  I can't help wondering about the data, such as conflating Covid with some chronic condition, or even worse, recording Covid as cause of death when the patient maybe very old snf carrying serious chronic ailments,  Also, it's clear there are lags in reporting as well as inconsistencies even just in the US.

In the last week there were ~5900 deaths. As cases have increased about 20% in the past 2 weeks, we can expect about 7000 deaths in two weeks, as there appears to be an approximately 2-3 week lag between cases and deaths. However, the spike up in deaths is smeared out compared to that in cases, so if the spike in cases subside I expect that deaths for the week ending 1st May would be 6000-7000.
